curriculum_stages.name: Basic Hit or Stand
curriculum_stages.description: The agent learns the fundamental strategy of when to hit (draw another card) or stand (stay with the current hand). The agent must learn to avoid busting by hitting on high totals and understand the relative value of its hand compared to the dealer's upcard. No splitting or doubling down is allowed in this stage to simplify the learning process.

curriculum_stages.name: Doubling Down
curriculum_stages.description: This stage introduces the 'Double Down' action. The agent must now learn when doubling down is advantageous. This requires understanding situations where the initial hand total has a high probability of winning against the dealer's upcard, and adjusting its strategy accordingly. The increased complexity forces the agent to reassess the risk/reward ratio.

curriculum_stages.name: Splitting Pairs
curriculum_stages.description: In this stage, the 'Split' action is introduced, allowing the agent to split pairs into two separate hands. The agent needs to learn the optimal strategy for splitting pairs based on the dealer's upcard. Understanding when to split Aces, eights or other valuable pairs is crucial for increasing the chances of winning. This stage focuses solely on splitting, and prevents the 'Double Down' action.

curriculum_stages.name: Full Blackjack
curriculum_stages.description: The agent now has access to all available actions: Hit, Stand, Double Down, and Split. This is the full Blackjack game, requiring the agent to integrate all previously learned strategies and make complex decisions based on the current state. This is the most challenging stage, as the agent must learn to balance the use of all available actions for optimal play.
